You know him .

I will explain a situation to you .

Thankfully no panic broke out otherwise the whole situation wouldn't have ended that harmlessly .
You see that in a crisis situation , in a starting catastrophe , communication is a very important good .
Communication is important because the people in this situation long for communication .
They want to know that is going on .
Earlier in the good old days , it was easier for the authorities .
We just didn't say anything or lied .
Why ?
Because the so-called panic myth prevailed .
One has justified by saying that , oh my Good , the people will panic , so it would be better not to tell the truth or to tell the untruth .

In a time of social media , in a time of Twitter , in a time of Facebook , in a time of private and public broadcasting companies , in a time of private and public television this is not possible any more .
Plain and simple because first , it is not ethical and second , we as an authority are most of the time the last ones who report on the events .
You may remember the plane crash in the Hudson River some years ago .
The first announcement came via Twitter .
From someone who was on a ferry and plain and simple immediately tweeted , a plan had crashed here and we are saving the people now .
This wasn't communication of the authorities .
As you can see we plain and simple need to tell the truth right from the beginning on today and to provide a lot of information .
Because most of the time we are the last ones who are supposed to know the truth , because we as authorities have to check that we do only spread reliable information .
Public media or also private media are either not as bound to this as we are or they just don't do it .
Therefore , we in Essen , and this is something that has already dominated the media , have thought about how to deal with disaster communication in the future .
And therefore , we will get out the good old horn .
However , only as a medium for the first communication .
This means that in the following years , we will install about one hundred horns in the city region which , some of you may still know it , will start blaring in the case of a catastrophe .
In former times that was it .
You know , maybe you remember what the signal three times short , one time short , one time long and one time short means .
I don't know it any more .

Today , we want to combine this with all communication possibilities we have , such as multimedia , via Facebook , via Twitter , via the radio of course and even at night , via television and in general via Internet and the local media and so on and so forth , connected of course with telephone switchboards in order to finally transfer the information .
And we know that we have to act fast and thoroughly and we know that we have to inform fast an thoroughly because otherwise we will irritate the citizens .
And they will finally not believe any more what we want to tell them .
Thus , communication during a crisis in one the one hand a question of rapidity via all media we have and it is a question of trustworthiness .
Trustworthiness is our biggest problem because either the citizens say , well , they are just exaggerating , it is not true , they lie and everything is worse than it is in reality .
We have had a positive experience with Facebook and Twitter , just recently .
You , some of you may have heard of this in the media .

The whole story had an immense effect for us since the trustworthiness was significantly higher via social media .

How we are going to die .
Regarding this , I need to tell you about Rosalinde first .
Rosalinde was a patient in the hospital where I am in charge of the radiology department , and she had fallen .
She was over ninety years old and always loved dancing into May because it also made her remember her husband , her first husband , who had died in the war .

And so she went to dance every year on the first of May and danced until late and probably drank a glass of punch too much once and ended up falling and broke , you can see it here on the right side , her leg , her femoral neck .
She had already fallen once a couple of years before and had broken her left leg in the same way at the same occasion .

And at that time I was already working there as a doctor and saw how she spent weeks in the intensive care unit , how she was treated with antibiotics , also how she was resuscitated , and I overheard the discussion in which was said , does this even make sense after all ?
Does it even make sense to use such intensive methods to treat a person that old ?
That is to resuscitate , to give artificial respiration , in the intensive care unit for weeks , can you even expose somebody to that ?
And she was healed then .

Five years later I come into the clinic , see the name Rosalinde , and I can easily remember it because it is just so rare , even at that time , and she had , when she had been dancing into May , broken her other leg .
This raises the question , what is it actually that I discuss when I talk about how a person has to decide for himself what he writes in his living will or which health care proxies he signs ?
And this is more or less what the talk is about .
Here you see the forefather of the name , how we are going to die .
It is a nineteen-ninety-seven book , how we are going to work , a report to the Club-of-Rome .
And at that time glottalization was advancing in such a strong way that you asked yourself , what can interconnected work look like ?
So they said , and you can still look that up in the book today , there will be a quality control , so that the parts always fit together .
There will be an interconnection of work processes , there will also be much more outsourcing , to China for example , that was a major topic at that time .

And this is how it turned out then , that basically the work of the individual , that is assembling something , manufacturing something , was becoming worth less and less , that there was more and more control also of the quality he delivers , of the accuracy .

And that , in my estimation , people were less and less confident of their work and became more and more part of a little wheelwork , which was all about achieving the highest value creation possible , and not about also defining yourself by your work anymore .
And now if we apply this to the nursing care and medical sector , then , of course , there is a similar development .
When you hear on TV what doctors , nurses , and also geriatric nurses complain about most , it 's the so called documentation requirements .

And this means they have to document what they have done so that it is enforceable , so that it gets even paid at all , and if it isn't documented , the Medical Service might say , we will not pay this care or this medical treatment .

But because of this documentation the work of the nurses increasingly loses its value and the thought of fulfilling one's task and contributing it with commitment out of personal conviction is being neglected while they are being controlled , punished , and not considered credible .

A good friend of mine has gone to Holland now , because he had enough of how things were done here , he had a general medical practice , gave it up and went to Holland to become a geriatric physician .

More often than not , the Dutch are a step ahead when it comes to developments like this and what he , Martin , had experienced was that more and more old people commute between nursing home , hospital , back and forth , because the nursing home didn't know what to do anymore when a person's health declined .
They are hospitalized then , have their health restored , go back to the retirement home or nursing home and are further looked after .

And so this general practitioner had thought , if in Holland there is something organized like this , then I would like to be trained there in order to promote some change here , so that there is a chance to escape from this vicious cycle of lacking credibility and undignified treatment of human beings .

Now , having arrived there in Holland , after it had taken him a lot of effort to learn the language , he had to discover that what is happening there is exactly what happened in this how-we-are-going-to-work .
Dying , too , is more and more subject to an introduction of quality control .
Credibility is no longer what counts , but at one point in an injunction you determine , for example , I don't want to be resuscitated or I don't want to be hospitalized when I am in a nursing home .
And this is respected then .

In the Netherlands it goes like this , on the third day , a conversation is held with the newly arrived residents , and then they have to decide , do I want to be hospitalized or do I not want to be hospitalized anymore , if something happens to me .
It's the same with , I want to be resuscitated or I don't want to be resuscitated .
This data is sent to the central administration and that's where this geriatric physician is , who always has the medical records before him and decides on this basis .

Now if we think back to Rosalinde , who as I said liked dancing into May and had fallen once , and we imagine that at some point she had written a living will stating , I don't want to be resuscitated , then this second dancing into May , where , admittedly , she fell a second time , she would not have lived to see .
And now my friend , who is over there in Holland , is worrying about how to deal with this .

In fact , today , about sixty to seventy per cent of people do not die at home anymore , but in hospitals , nursing facilities , and on top of that , these nursing facilities are , you can see it that way , not the ideal living space for elderly people after all , but there is often a financially narrow leeway , the nursing staff is often over-strained and the promotion in itself of being alive happens , in my opinion , only to a limited extend .

Certainly , there are homes in which this is done very well , there are very enthusiastic people who get involved there , but when I look at the overall balance , and we have twelve thousand patients per year , so about five , six thousand perhaps , who are perhaps admitted to us from the nursing homes , then I personally would say , it is indeed difficult to get along there and keep up your inner self-confidence .

Of course , this whole issue has pecuniary reasons , that's for sure , this whole quality control , this control has been established because after all there is not enough money for all people to be taken care of in the best possible way and in full scope , and for the people who provide the care or the medical treatments to be payed in such a way that they can say , I'm doing fine with this , I as a nurse can , for example , feed a family with one or two children .
This simply isn't today's reality , but you need two incomes in the nursing and geriatric sector and in most cases even this is just enough .
This introduction of quality control as a consequence of a steadily growing market one wants to regulate also has an impact for the concerned individuals .

And now I come to how one might be able to evade this , so what do we do after all , because I have started by asked questions and have shown that the situation is not all that easy for the persons concerned .

And in this respect I have simply dusted off the German basic law and picked out article one , because I think a society always needs structures like this , legal structures also , which serve as a foundation for the whole thing , for what happens in our society .
And after all in the basic law article one it says , human dignity shall be inviolable .
And the second sentence there says , to protect it shall be the duty of all state authority .
And what I sometimes miss is yet a third sentence saying that each individual person for himself should also have the mission to protect and defend his dignity .

Because this is a way to free yourself from this trap where you say I pass this on to others and they shall somehow look after me and take care of me so that at least I don't have to think much about how I am going to die one day .
Because after all that's how it is , although we don't like to face this matter , one day we will arrive at that point .
Hopefully not until late , at the age of hundred or a hundred and ten .

Of course , it is according to my job to say , I wish this for everyone and that's also what I want to provide for , but at some point one will have to face this subject , and then when this happens or simply , when you are seventy-five , eighty-five , or ninety-five , it can be late in life already , to say , I want to think about this question now .

When the time has come to think about it , what does my dignity consist of , then in the end you will think of aspects which reveal , what were the five most important things for me in my life after all ?
There is a book now that is quite in vogue .

It surely is the confidence between people , with which I might also be involved , in the geriatric sector or in the medical sector or a priest or a lawyer or another person with whom I enter into a relationship .
And of course there are many individual factors which play a role , I won't go through all of them now .
But when you start to consider these three points , then you have a number of tasks already , how you may have to orient yourself in life to protect your own dignity in the end .
And then there is another factor , that we experience a certain dictatorship of the do-gooders , I have taken this here as a text or as an example for that .
